BellCube","lastMod":"2023-3-13","isArticle":true,"permalink":"/about-me/","sm_priority":0.9,"description":"\"About Me\" for BellCube, a hobbyist video game modder and web developer. ","extra_head":"<link rel=\"preconnect\" href=\"https://github.com\"> <link rel=\"preconnect\" href=\"https://api.allorigins.win/raw\"> ","content":"<h1>Hello there!</h1> <p> I'm BellCube, a modder who works on Minecraft and various Bethesda games and a moderator at Nexus Mods. <br> I also like to code stuff. I'm currently learning web development (oh hi) and I'll just learn something else after that. <br> </p> <h2> What I Know </h2> <p> I primarily know TypeScript and Papyrus, though I have some experience with Lua. As for data formats, I can fluently write JSON and YAML, XML, and INI no problem. I can churn out HTML like it's nothing most of the time. CSS occasionally gives me some trouble, but nothing MDN can't fix. I can also write Batch and Powershell scripts relatively well. <br> If you need someone to right your regex, I'm your guy—I write it like a second language. I can usually figure out any given language if need be, but I prefer to use the ones I already know if possible. <br> <h3> The Bucket List </h3> In no particular order: <ul> <li> Getting familiar with databases (e.g. SQL) </li> <li> Learning C#, C++, Rust, and Python </li> <li> Accustoming myself to various JavaScript frameworks </li> <li> Familiarizing myself with the Linux command line </li> </ul> <style> rect[fill=\"#ddd\"] { fill: #333; } </style> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" style=\"transform: scale(1.5) translateX(-26px); transform-origin: top left; height: 320px;\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/top-langs/?username=BellCubeDev&langs_count=5&hide=JavaScript,Ruby,Nix&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"> </div> <br> <br> </p> <h2> Outside of Programming and Modding </h2> <p> I'm a film student IRL. While I haven't published any work just yet, that may change at some point in the next three years. My all-time favorite game is Hollow Knight—the most perfect game known to man. I've got a backlog longer than the Pacific Ocean and twice as deep (thanks, Nexus!). I'm an English fanatic and can be found occasionally losing my last few drops of sanity over simple things like a missing comma. </p> <h2> Moderation </h2> <p> On March 1st, 2023 at 10:18 AM EST, Nexus' community manager <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.nexusmods.com/users/31179975\">Pickysaurus</a> contacted me via Discord to ask if I was interested in helping moderate Nexus Mods. I said yes after a bit of discussion and was officially knighted on the 6th. I strive to be fair and objective from the moment I open the reports panel, though I'm not perfect. I do my best to always back up my actions with direct citation from official Nexus policies and do my best to ask my fellow moderators and the Community Management team when I'm unsure of something. <br><br> Moderation is volunteer work, so I don't get paid for it. I do it because I mainly because I enjoy it, though the want to help make Nexus a better place for everyone certainly doesn't hurt. <br><br> If you ever want more information on how I moderate, feel free to <a href=\"#get-in-touch\">ask me about it</a>. I'm always happy to answer as best I can and dig further if I can't! </p> <br> <hr> <br> <div class=\"centered\"> <h2>Current Projects</h2> <style> .js-dom-svg { clip-path: inset(0 0 100% 0); max-height: 0; transition-property: clip-path, max-height; transition-duration: 500ms; } .js-dom-svg--loaded { max-height: 100%; clip-path: inset(0 0 0 0); } </style> <div class=\"bcd-projects\"> <!-- https://github.com/anuraghazra/github-readme-stats is meant for GitHub profile readmes, but do I look like I care? This section is generated by iterating over projects found in the `projects.yaml` file in the `_data` folder. --> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/BellCubeDev.GitHub.IO\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=BellCubeDev.GitHub.IO&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/AdditionalClockwork\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=AdditionalClockwork&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> </div> <h2>Fallen-By-The-Wayside Projects</h2> <style> .js-dom-svg { clip-path: inset(0 0 100% 0); max-height: 0; transition-property: clip-path, max-height; transition-duration: 500ms; } .js-dom-svg--loaded { max-height: 100%; clip-path: inset(0 0 0 0); } </style> <div class=\"bcd-projects\"> <!-- https://github.com/anuraghazra/github-readme-stats is meant for GitHub profile readmes, but do I look like I care? This section is generated by iterating over projects found in the `projects.yaml` file in the `_data` folder. --> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/LinearSpellProgression\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=LinearSpellProgression&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> </div> <h2>Completed Projects</h2> <style> .js-dom-svg { clip-path: inset(0 0 100% 0); max-height: 0; transition-property: clip-path, max-height; transition-duration: 500ms; } .js-dom-svg--loaded { max-height: 100%; clip-path: inset(0 0 0 0); } </style> <div class=\"bcd-projects\"> <!-- https://github.com/anuraghazra/github-readme-stats is meant for GitHub profile readmes, but do I look like I care? This section is generated by iterating over projects found in the `projects.yaml` file in the `_data` folder. --> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/Breadward\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=Breadward&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/full-uri-escaper\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=full-uri-escaper&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> <a target=\"_blank\" class=\"gh-stats-card\" href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/WoodworkersWhim\"> <div class=\"js-dom-svg\" src=\"https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/pin?username=BellCubeDev&repo=WoodworkersWhim&theme=github_dark&title-color=329cff&icon_color=ffd43b&bg_color=0000&hide_border=true\"></div> </a> </div> <h2>Archived Projects</h2> <style> .js-dom-svg { clip-path: inset(0 0 100% 0); max-height: 0; transition-property: clip-path, max-height; transition-duration: 500ms; } .js-dom-svg--loaded { max-height: 100%; clip-path: inset(0 0 0 0); } </style> <div class=\"bcd-projects\"> <!-- https://github.com/anuraghazra/github-readme-stats is meant for GitHub profile readmes, but do I look like I care? This section is generated by iterating over projects found in the `projects.yaml` file in the `_data` folder. --> <p>Nothing here yet...</p> </div> </div> <br> <hr> <br> <h2> Get In Touch </h2> <p> If you want to get in touch with me, you can do so via the following methods: <ul> <li> <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://forums.nexusmods.com/index.php?app=members&module=messaging&section=send&do=form&fromMemberID=98340728\">Nexus Mods DMs</a> </li> <li> Discord - <code>BellCube#9773</code> (you'll have to be in a server with me, such as the <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://discord.gg/nexusmods\">Nexus Mods server</a>) </li> </ul> </p> ","dir":"/about-me/","name":"about-me.html","path":"about-me.html","url":"/about-me/"},{"layout":"docs","navType":"LSProgression","title":"LSP - Creating a Plugin","permalink":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin/","redirect_from":["/documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin"],"lastMod":"2022-11-23","description":"This page describes how to create a plugin for the Linear Spell Progression framework mod. It runs through the basics, such as the structure, all the way down to the standard Editor IDs. Linear Spell Progression is a Skyrim Special Edition framework mod that allows you to add prerequisites to spells without creating compatibility issues. ","content":"<h1>The Format</h1> Linear Spell Progression has its own format for plugins. First, download the Plugin Development Kit from <a href=\"https://github.com/BellCubeDev/LinearSpellProgression/releases\" target=\"_blank\">releases</a>. Below is an overview of the plugin and a guide to editing it. For testing, use <a href=\"https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/43095/\" target=\"_blank\">Don't Eat Spell Tomes.</a> <h2>Plugin Structure</h2> The plugin is made of a Package and at least 4 FormLists, arranged in a tree structure. <div class=\"js-bcd-summary\" for=\"docs_lsp_createPlugin_diagram_img\"> <i class=\"material-icons open-icon-90CC\">expand_more</i> <h3>Image Diagram</h3> </div> <div class=\"js-bcd-details\" id=\"docs_lsp_createPlugin_diagram_img\"> <img src=\"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BellCubeDev/LinearSpellProgression/main/Images/LSP%20Master%20List%20Format.svg\" loading=\"lazy\" alt=\"an image-based diagram of the Linear Spell Progression plugin format\" /> </div> <div class=\"js-bcd-summary\" for=\"docs_lsp_createPlugin_diagram_txt\"> <i class=\"material-icons open-icon-90CC\">expand_more</i> <h3>Text Representation</h3> </div> <div class=\"js-bcd-details\" id=\"docs_lsp_createPlugin_diagram_txt\"> <ul class=\"docs_textDiagram\"> <li>Master List (in LinearSpellProgression.esl)<ul type=\"disc\"> <ul> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">YOUR Plugin! (Repeatable) <ol type=\"1\" start=\"0\"> <li>Spell Tomes <ol type=\"1\" start=\"0\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell Tome (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell Tome (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell Tome (Repeatable)</li> </ol> </li> <li>Spells <ol type=\"1\" start=\"0\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Matching Spell (repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Matching Spell (repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Matching Spell (repeatable)</li> </ol> </li> <li>Prerequisite Spells <ol type=\"1\" start=\"0\"> <li>Spell 0's Prerequisites <ul type=\"square\"> <li>Single Spell</li> <li>Requirements List <ul type=\"circle\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Spell 1's Prerequisites <ul type=\"square\"> <li>Single Spell</li> <li>Requirements List <ul type=\"circle\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> <li>Spell 2's Prerequisites <ul type=\"square\"> <li>Single Spell</li> <li>Requirements List <ul type=\"circle\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Some Spell (Repeatable)</li> </ul> </li> </ul> </li> </ol> </li> <li>Spells <ol type=\"1\" start=\"0\"> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Skill Level Global (repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Skill Level Global (repeatable)</li> <li class=\"docs_textDiagram_repeatable\">Skill Level Global (repeatable)</li> </ol> </li> </ol> </li> </ul> </li> </ul> </div> <h2>Package??!</h2> <p> A quick look in xEdit shows that the template includes an AI Package??! What in the world? Well, allow me to enlighten you. I've used the Package to hold the script needed to install your plugin. Why not use a Quest, you might ask. Well, I've heard reports about the OnInit() event having oddities and inconsistencies on Quests, and so I opted for another form that can hold scripts—and opted for packages. Because they're not a base object (like an Activator or Static), I don't expect xSE plugins to mess with it (causing a very minor performance hit). And because of its EditorID, I don't expect users to attempt to apply it to an NPC. </p> <h1>The Guide</h1> <p> Alright, so now you know what that's all about. You may even understand this enough to jump in right now! But if you're not, here's what you do: <ol> <li>Rename the plugin file. Don't want a bunch of plugins all called <code>LinearSpellProgression Plugin Template.esp</code>, now do we?</li> <li>Open the Plugin Template, alongside any plugins you want to add spell prerequisites to, in either <a href=\"https://www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/164/\">SSEEdit</a> (Recommended) or the Creation Kit.</li> <li>Navigate to the FormLists. If you're doing this in the Creation Kit, you can search by <code>LSP_</code></li> <li>Rename the FormLists using the <a href=\"#editorid-scheme\">EditorID Scheme</a> below</li> <li>Balance to your heart's content! Here's how: <ol type=\"1\"> <li>Find your Spell Tome. Add it to the Tomes list.</li> <li>Add its corresponding Spell to the Spells list</li> <li>Add its prerequisites to the Prerequisites list. This can be <b><u>EITHER</u></b> a FormList <b>or</b> a single Spell</li> </ol> <br /> Do note these items' indexes must align. So if the Spell Tome for Fireball is at index 2, the spell Fireball should be at index 2 in the Spells list and the various prerequisites should be at index 2 in the Prerequisites lists. </li> </ol> Simple enough, right? (if you don't think so, think of how annoying this would be to implement on your own) </p> <h1>EditorID Scheme</h1> It's a (relatively) simple system. <ul> <li> Universal Ending: <span class=nested_code><code>[DLC/CC/MOD]</code>{{3-letter abbreviation for author, such as BGS}}<code>_</code>{{2-Digit Number}}{{Human-readable name}}</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> <br /><br /> </li> <li> Plugin-Level: <span class=nested_code><code>LSP_Main_</code> + Universal Ending</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>LSP_0Tomes_DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> <br /><br /> </li> <li> Tome: <span class=nested_code><code>LSP_0Tomes_</code> + Universal Ending</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>LSP_0Tomes_DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> <br /><br /> </li> <li> * Spells: <span class=nested_code><code>LSP_1Spells_</code> + Universal Ending</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>LSP_1Spells_DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> <br /><br /> </li> <li> Prerequisites: <span class=nested_code><code>LSP_2Pre_</code> + Universal Ending</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>LSP_2Pre_DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> <br /><br /> </li> <li> List of a single spell's prerequisites: <span class=nested_code><code>LSP_</code>{{Spell Name}}<code>_</code> + Universal Ending</span><br /> <i>Example: <code>LSP_FlameCloak_DLC_BGS_00Skyrim</code></i> </li> </ul> ","dir":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin/","name":"creating-a-plugin.html","path":"documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin.html","url":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin/"},{"layout":"page","title":"Debug Page - Extended","description":"Page for debugging stuff. id=\"no-support-modal\" class=\"js-bcd-modal\"> <div class=\"js-bcd-modal-body\"> <h1>Support Notice</h1> <p>The FOMOD Builder is currently only supported on desktop systems running Chromium-based browsers. While I do eventually plan to provide support for Firefox, Safari, and the like, Chromium-based browsers include powerful web APIs for things like <a href=\"https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File_System_Access_API\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">manipulation of files and directories</a> that the FOMOD Builder relies on at the moment. In the future, support for other browsers maybe added.</p> <br /> <br /> <p>Your browser does not support at least one of the APIs tested. Please use a different browser. You may still exit this dialog and attempt to use the FOMOD Builder, however BellCube makes no guarantees as to whether or not it will work.</p> <hr /> <h2> Missing APIs: </h2> <p class=\"replace_me_txt\"></p> </div> <div autofocus class=\"js-bcd-modal-buttons\"> <button class=\"js-bcd-modal-close mdl-button mdl-js-button mdl-js-ripple-effect mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored\" width=\"128\">Close</button> </div> </dialog> <dialog id=\"opening-other-project-modal\" class=\"js-bcd-modal\"> <div class=\"js-bcd-modal-body\"> <h1>Opening Another Project</h1> <p>Are you sure you want to open another project? If it is not set up for a FOMOD just yet, no worries! </p></div> <button type=\"button\" onclick=\"window.FOMODBuilder.ui.save()\" class=\"mdl-button mdl-js-button mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored mdl-js-ripple-effect bcd-button-save\"> Save </button> <button type=\"button\" onclick=\"window.FOMODBuilder.ui.cleanSave()\" class=\"mdl-button mdl-js-button mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored mdl-js-ripple-effect bcd-button-save\"> Clean Save </button> <div class=\"js-bcd-tooltip\" tooltip-relation=\"proceeding\" tooltip-position=\"bottom\"><p> Will nuke your current file and reconstruct it from the ground up. This can be dangerous if you've manually commented on the file, however it also ensures that the FOMOD is schema-compliant—which can fix most instances of Vortex rejecting the installer due to non-compliance. </p></div> <button disabled=\"visual\" type=\"button\" onclick=\"window.FOMODBuilder.ui.attemptRepair()\" class=\"mdl-button w192 mr8 mdl-js-button mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored mdl-js-ripple-effect\"> Attempt FOMOD Repair </button> <div class=\"js-bcd-tooltip\" tooltip-relation=\"proceeding\" tooltip-position=\"bottom\"><p> Will attempt to repair a FOMOD that is not schema-compliant. This page endevours to explain its inner-workings ","content":"<h1> How It Works - For Nerds </h1> Linear Spell Progression consumes and stores data in a structure of FormLists intended to represent Objects and Arrays in developed, object-oriented programming languages. ","dir":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/how-it-works/","name":"how-it-works.html","path":"documentation/linear-spell-progression/how-it-works.html","url":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/how-it-works/"},{"layout":"page","title":"The Home of A Decent Hobbyist Programmer","sitemap":false,"content":"","dir":"/tools/","name":"index.html","path":"tools/index.html","url":"/tools/"},{"layout":"page","title":"Home","formatted_title":"BellCube - A Decent Hobbyist Programmer","lastMod":"2023-3-13","isArticle":true,"description":"The website for BellCube, a hobbyist video game modder and web developer. The site hosts documentation, tools, and project updates—and possibly the occasional blog post. Best of all, it's all open-source! BellCube can be found on GitHub and Nexus Mods as well. ","extra_head":"<link rel=\"preconnect\" href=\"https://github.com\"> ","content":"<h1>Hello there!</h1> <p> I'm BellCube, a modder who works on Minecraft and various Bethesda games. <br /><br /> This is my personal website—a place where I post documentation, tools, and updates on my projects. Maybe the occasional blog post? 🤷‍♂️ <br /><br /> You can find some fancy links in the Navigation Drawer to the left. A full-blown \"About Me,\" a section for Documentation, and some links to my GitHub and Nexus Mods profiles (hover your mouse over the Nexus Mods one for a treat!). </p> <br /> <hr /> <br /> <div class=\"centered\"> {% include projects.html %} </div> ","dir":"/","name":"index.html","path":"index.html","url":"/"},{"layout":"docs","navType":"LSProgression","title":"Linear Spell Progression","permalink":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/","redirect_from":["/documentation/linear-spell-progression"],"lastMod":"2022-11-23","description":"Linear Spell Progression is a Skyrim Special Edition framework mod that allows you to add prerequisites to spells without creating compatibility issues. ","content":"<h1>Linear Spell Progression</h1> Linear Spell Progression (LSP) is a framework developed by me, BellCube Dev, for easily and conflictlessly adding spell prerequisites. You can read about <a href=\"{% link documentation/linear-spell-progression/how-it-works.html %}\">How It Works - For Nerds</a> or <a href=\"{% link documentation/linear-spell-progression/linear-spell-progression.html %}\">Creating a Plugin</a> here on this wiki. <h2>Compatibility</h2> <i>tl;dr: This is probably the most compatible mod with a plugin in your entire load order</i> <br /> Linear Spell Progression is designed in every aspect to be as compatible as possible. It makes a grand total of zero record overrides (in laymen's terms, it does not edit anything directly), it does not require any DLC, and it only takes action when directed to by other plugins. <h2>Creating LSP Plugins</h2> Designed with modularity in mind, LSP plugins are as simple to create as the engine allows, and can easily be done entirely through xEdit. See <a href=\"{% link documentation/linear-spell-progression/creating-a-plugin.html %}\">the full guide</a> for the full run-down. ","dir":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/","name":"linear-spell-progression.html","path":"documentation/linear-spell-progression/linear-spell-progression.html","url":"/documentation/linear-spell-progression/"},{"layout":"page","title":"Tools - Papyrus Auto Docs","extra_head":"<script async type=\"module\" src=\"papyrus-docs.js\" onload=\"callInit('papyDocs')\"></script> ","lastMod":"2022-11-23","description":"The Papyrus Auto Docs tool generates Markdown documentation for Papyrus scripts largely automatically. It includes options for both batch processing and single-file processing. ","permalink":"/tools/papyrus/markdown-docs/","redirect_from":["/tools/papy/markdown-docs/","/tools/papyrus/docs/","/tools/papy/docs/","/tools/papyrus/markdown/","/tools/papy/markdown/","/tools/papyrus/md-docs/","/tools/papy/md-docs/","/tools/papyrus-markdown-docs/","/tools/papy-markdown-docs/","/tools/papyrus/docs/","/tools/papy/docs/","/tools/papyrus/markdown/","/tools/papy/markdown/","/tools/papyrus/md-docs/","/tools/papy/md-docs/"],"content":"<h1>Papyrus Markdown Docs Generator</h1> <p>This page is a utility for generating bare-bones Markdown documentation for Papyrus scripts. <br /> It can either process a single file and output the Markdown below—<b><i>or</i></b> it can process an entire directory recursively, outputting the Markdown as files by the same name, but with the <code>md</code> extension appended. <br /> This page was build with generating documentation for <a href=\"https://modding.wiki\" target=\"_blank\">Modding.wiki</a> in mind.</p> </p> <div class=\"warning-block\"> <h3 style=\"margin-bottom:2px\">IMPORTANT:</h3> <p>This tool is currently only intended for use with Skyrim Papyrus scripts. Fallout 4 Papyrus support may come at a later date.</p> </div> <div class=\"danger-block\"> <h3 style=\"margin-bottom:2px\">WARNING:</h3> <p>DO NOT simply copy-paste to the wiki! To provide coherent documentation, you should review each element with care. No generator is perfect, and programmers infamously do not document their code. The documentation extracted here may be lacking or even non-existent.</p> </div> <button id=\"papy_docs_folder-picker\" type=\"button\" style=\"width:160px;margin-right:8px;\" class=\"mdl-button mdl-js-button mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored mdl-js-ripple-effect bcd-button-openDir\"> Select Directory </button> <div class=\"js-bcd-tooltip\" tooltip-relation=\"proceeding\" tooltip-position=\"bottom\"><p> Select an entire directory for batch processing. <code>.psc</code> files will be parsed and the documentation will be outputted as <code>.psc.md</code> files alongside the original files. WILL overwrite existing files. </p></div> <button id=\"papy_docs_file-picker\" type=\"button\" style=\"width:118px\" class=\"mdl-button mdl-js-button mdl-button--raised mdl-button--colored mdl-js-ripple-effect bcd-button-openFile\"> Select File </button> <div class=\"js-bcd-tooltip\" tooltip-relation=\"proceeding\" tooltip-position=\"bottom\"><p> Select a single file for processing. pages.title: Tools - FOMOD Builder
pages.description: The FOMOD Builder is a tool for creating FOMOD installers, a popular XML-based format for video game mod installers. It is the first of its kind to feature intuitive tooltips, dark mode, and eventually more. It is, at this time, incomplete.
pages.content:
"/assets/site/css/vortex_fomod.css"

Support Notice

The FOMOD Builder is currently only supported on desktop systems running Chromium-based browsers. While I do eventually plan to provide support for Firefox, Safari, and the like, Chromium-based browsers include powerful web APIs for things like manipulation of files and directories that the FOMOD Builder relies on at the moment. In the future, support for other browsers maybe added.



Your browser does not support at least one of the APIs tested. Please use a different browser. You may still exit this dialog and attempt to use the FOMOD Builder, however BellCube makes no guarantees as to whether or not it will work.

Missing APIs:

Opening Another Project

Are you sure you want to open another project? There is already one open!

This is the folder that you will put into an archive to be installed by users. If it is not set up for a FOMOD just yet, no worries!

Will nuke your current file and reconstruct it from the ground up. This can be dangerous if you've manually commented on the file, however it also ensures that the FOMOD is schema-compliant—which can fix most instances of Vortex rejecting the installer due to non-compliance.

Will attempt to repair a FOMOD that is not schema-compliant. Will try to fix typos in the XML and remove elements that do not appear to be typos. THIS IS DANGEROUS! MAKE A BACKUP AND USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!


Explore the FOMOD Builder in all its glory, no folder required! This will load a test FOMOD that is included with the program. It may well be possible to use this on an unsupported browser; however, it is not recommended.

This will make the raw file easier to read but will increase the size of the generated files.<br><hr>This setting has no impact on the functionality of the FOMOD."}}

Tab: Metadata

This field is not technically used by Mod Organizer 2 or Vortex. That said, MO2's parser does assign the value to an unused variable that shares a name with the Nexus Mods Page ID elsewhere in its code.



This value must be a whole number. It is recommended that you create a mod page and use the page's Nexus Mods ID for this field.

The author of the mod.



This value is only read and displayed during FOMOD installation by Mod Organizer 2. It is not used by Vortex.

The version of the mod. I suggest using Semantic Versioning (aka SemVer) for this field.



This value is only read and displayed during FOMOD installation by Mod Organizer 2. It is not used by Vortex.

If specified, this should be a valid URI

A link to the mod's website.


This value is only read and accessible as a hyperlink during FOMOD installation by Mod Organizer 2. It is not used by Vortex.

Mod Name

Step Sorting Order

pages.title: LSP - How It Works - For Nerds
pages.description:
Linear Spell Progression is a Skyrim Special Edition framework mod that allows you to add prerequisites to spells without creating compatibility issues.
With complexity increases exponentially with ease of use, and so it stands that Linear Spell Progression is relatively complex. This page endevours to explain its inner-workings
pages.content:
How It Works - For Nerds

Linear Spell Progression consumes and stores data in a structure of FormLists intended to represent Objects and Arrays in developed, object-oriented programming languages.

pages.description:
The website for BellCube, a hobbyist video game modder and web developer. The site hosts documentation, tools, and project updates—and possibly the occasional blog post. Best of all, it's all open-source!
BellCube can be found on GitHub and Nexus Mods as well.
pages.content:
Hello there!

I'm BellCube, a modder who works on Minecraft and various Bethesda games.

This is my personal website—a place where I post documentation, tools, and updates on my projects. Maybe the occasional blog post? 🤷‍♂️

You can find some fancy links in the Navigation Drawer to the left. A full-blown "About Me," a section for Documentation, and some links to my GitHub and Nexus Mods profiles (hover your mouse over the Nexus Mods one for a treat!).

pages.title: Linear Spell Progression
pages.description: Linear Spell Progression is a Skyrim Special Edition framework mod that allows you to add prerequisites to spells without creating compatibility issues.
pages.content:
Linear Spell Progression

Linear Spell Progression (LSP) is a framework developed by me, BellCube Dev, for easily and conflictlessly adding spell prerequisites. You can read about How It Works - For Nerds or Creating a Plugin here on this wiki.

Compatibility

tl;dr: This is probably the most compatible mod with a plugin in your entire load order
Linear Spell Progression is designed in every aspect to be as compatible as possible. It makes a grand total of zero record overrides (in laymen's terms, it does not edit anything directly), it does not require any DLC, and it only takes action when directed to by other plugins.

Creating LSP Plugins

Designed with modularity in mind, LSP plugins are as simple to create as the engine allows, and can easily be done entirely through xEdit. See the full guide for the full run-down.

pages.title: Tools - Papyrus Auto Docs
pages.description: The Papyrus Auto Docs tool generates Markdown documentation for Papyrus scripts largely automatically. It includes options for both batch processing and single-file processing.
pages.content:
Papyrus Markdown Docs Generator

This page is a utility for generating bare-bones Markdown documentation for Papyrus scripts.
It can either process a single file and output the Markdown below—or it can process an entire directory recursively, outputting the Markdown as files by the same name, but with the md extension appended.
This page was build with generating documentation for Modding.wiki in mind.

IMPORTANT:

This tool is currently only intended for use with Skyrim Papyrus scripts. Fallout 4 Papyrus support may come at a later date.

WARNING:

DO NOT simply copy-paste to the wiki! To provide coherent documentation, you should review each element with care. No generator is perfect, and programmers infamously do not document their code. The documentation extracted here may be lacking or even non-existent.

Select an entire directory for batch processing. .psc files will be parsed and the documentation will be outputted as .psc.md files alongside the original files. WILL overwrite existing files.

Select a single file for processing. The documentation will be outputted in the below text area.


The name of the library. For instance, Vanilla.

Modding.wiki-relative URL to the library's folder page.

Case-insensitive scheme to look for when trying to detect Event Registration functions. %e% is substituted for the event's name (with some words, common prefixes, and common suffixes removed).

The default (RegisterFor%e%) will serve just fine for vanilla. 

# Markdown Output

Here, you'll find the `Markdown` that you generate from ***single*** files (or the *last* file in the selected folder) above.

* Thanks to [highlight_js](https://highlightjs.org/), we have fancy highlighting here!
pages.name: papyrus-docs.html

pages.content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><?xml-model href="https://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9/sitemap.xsd" type="application/xml" schematypens="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  {% for page in site.html_pages %}
    {% if page.sitemap != false and page.index != false and page.layout != 'compress_html' %}
      <url>
        <loc>{{ site.mainurl }}{{ page.url }}</loc>
        <lastmod>{{ page.lastMod | date_to_xmlschema }}</lastmod>
        {% if page.layout == 'docs' %}
          <priority>{{ page.sm_priority | default: 1 }}</priority>
        {% else %}
          <priority>{{ page.sm_priority | default: 0.5 }}</priority>
        {% endif %}
      </url>
    {% endif %}
  {% endfor %}

</urlset>
pages.name: sitemap.xml

pages.title: Tools - Typescript From Inline Sources
pages.description: A quick tool to quickly extract TypeScript source code that was emitted into a JavaScript file using the `inlineSources` compile option.
pages.content:
Typescript From Inline Sources

When using the inlineSources compiler option, TypeScript will emit the source code of the file into the JavaScript file as a data URI. This tool will extract the source code from the data URI and display for you, allowing you to easily use it for other things.
